results.title: Queensland's first films 1895-1910
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Almost all of Queensland’s film production for the 1890s has survived, and it offers a rare opportunity to see Australias colonial era come to life. This video contains highlights of the motion picture legacy of the of the pioneering exhibitors and filmmakers. Thoroughly researched and narrated by film historian Chris Long, this video opens a window into the colonial era and is a timely reminder of the crucial role played by factual film in the film in the first hundred years of cinema.

results.title: Border images: Albury-Wodonga 1920s-1970s
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Recapture the essence of Albury-Wodonga, the twin border cities on the Murray River. Delight in the landscapes of the past, recall the unique growth and progress of these twin cities: Hume Weir construction ; the intrigue of the Pyjama Murder mystery, travel on the Spirit of Progresses inaugural journey ; race in the 1930 Albury Gold Cup ; fly the Centenary Air Race with Bert Hinkler ; laugh with the old times of Albury-Wodonga and follow the frolicking fun of days gone by.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: Sons of Matthew
results.creator_credit: Charles Chauvel, Elsa Chauvel and Expeditionary Films
results.brief_description: This is the story of three generations of the O’Riordan family, battling bushfire, drought and cyclone to settle rugged frontier land. Based on the true story of the O’Reilly family, it took two years to make this film in the wild mountain terrain of southeastern Queensland. In this film Charles Chauvel realises his romantic vision of Australians as spirited rural people conquering a hostile land. Its power lies in the strong performances of the cast and in the striking landscape, which frames the human and elemental conflicts.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charles Chauvel, Elsa Chauvel and Expeditionary Films

results.title: Heritage
results.brief_description: Heritage explores 150 years of Australian history through the nationals myths of the visionary, the pioneer and the nation-builder. Opening with an historical re-enactment, this film evolves into a fictional story of the hard-living, hard-drinking James Morrison and his wife, fiery Irish girl, Biddy OShea. Although they go their separate ways, their paths and those of their children, cross as a nations destiny unfolds. Working with a very small budget , Chauvel was still able to achieve striking set pieces, such as the opening tableau. This film won the first prize in the 1935 Commonwealth Government film competition. For a nation emerging from the Great Depression, it showed pride in the past and faith in the future

results.title: Stolen moments
results.creator_credit: Margaret Wescott, Silva Basmajian and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Narrated by Kate Nelligan, the film takes us on an odyssey across North America and Europe to capture the ‘stolen moments’ of lesbian history. Lesbian culture in pre-war Paris, Berlin and Amsterdam; the experience of women in Nazi concentration camps; and the butch/femme scene in New York in the 1950s, are just a few aspects of lesbian history and identity explored in this provocative film. Writers Joan Nestle, Leslie Feinberg and Audrey Lorde share their insights of love, life, sexual politics and feminism. The film also explores such contemporary cultural scenes as women’s motorcycle clubs, dance bars, lesbian stand-up comedy, the Michigan Women’s Music Festival and lesbian athletes and their participation at the Vancouver Gay Games. A press kit complements the video and is issued as a separate loan item.

results.title: The Terence Davies trilogy: children: Madonna and child: death and transfiguration
results.creator_credit: Terence Davies, British Film Institute and National Film and Television School (Great Britain)
results.brief_description: Davies found the form in his partly autobiographical trilogy to transform Liverpudlian Robert Tucker’s development - from victimised schoolboy, in ‘Children’ (1976) through a Catholic repressed gay middle age ‘Madonna and Child’ (1980), to senility and death in hospital ‘Death and Transfiguration’ (1983) - into a rich, resonant tapestry of impressionistic detail. The bleakness is relieved by a wry wit, imaginative use of music and flashes of surrealism foreshadowing Davies’ subsequent autobiographies “Distant Voices, Still Lives” and “The Long Day Closes”. The trilogy is finally a spiritual work anchored firmly in the flux of everyday experience. Cast includes: ‘Children’; Phillip Maudsely (young Robert), Nick Stringer and Robin Hooper (Robert aged 23): ‘Madonna and child’; Terry O’Sullivan (Robert) and Sheila Raynor: ‘Death and transfiguration’; Wilfred Brambell (elderly Robert), Terry O’Sullivan (middle aged Robert), and Iain Munro.
results.title_for_label: The Terence Davies trilogy: children: Madonna and child: death and transfiguration

results.title: The Madigan Line
results.brief_description: One of the most inhospitable and desolate regions on Earth, the Simpson Desert was to fight off many challenges to penetrate its seemingly impenetrable heart. Expedition after expedition tried and failed. Men died but still they came. This video faithfully reenacts the 1939 expedition of Dr. Cecil Madigan who successfully crossed Australias last frontier.

results.title: The Joy Luck Club
results.creator_credit: Wayne Wang, Amy Tan, Patrick Markey, Ronald Bass and Hollywood Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on Amy Tan’s best-selling novel, “The Joy Luck Club” tells the story of two generations of Chinese women. Four are mothers and wives who emigrated from China to build new lives and families in the United States. The other four are their Chinese-American daughters who are struggling to define their own identities against the expectations of their mothers and the American society where they live. Wayne Wang masterfully interweaves the stories of the eight women which spans from feudal China to modern America, highlighting the similarities and differences between the two generations. “The Joy Luck Club” is a beautiful film to watch, with lavish production values which make the characters’ stories even more compelling.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wayne Wang, Amy Tan, Patrick Markey, Ronald Bass and Hollywood Pictures

results.title: Set no limits: Sydney 2000 Paralympic Games
results.brief_description: Australian Paralympians don’t often receive as much publicity as their non paralympic counterparts. This video attempts to even out the balance by providing highlights and victories from previous Paralympic Games, which began in 1960. Highlighted on the video is Lizzie (as in lizard), mascot of the Paralympic Games who symbolises the dreams and motivation of the competitors. This section is narrated by Olivia Newton-John. Suitable for primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Tripwire
results.creator_credit: Valerie Morton, David Hirst and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: A character and action driven true-life adventure documentary looking at the Australian Armys secret Norforce unit that forms this Island continents first line of defence across the remote Kimberly region and the Northern Territory. Norforce is also one of the msot dynamic experiments in inter-racial relations as the unit is made up of both white and Aboriginal Australians where the soldiers learn essential survival skills from each other. Narrated by Archie Roach, and featuring the music of the Warumpi Band.
